Study: Detection and isolation of asymptomatic individuals can make the difference in COVID-19 epidemic management
Factors: reduction in traveling between communities within the Mendoza province
Excerpt: outbreak reached the West with a 17-day lag (Ro=4) and a 42-day delay (Ro=2) when traveling between communities was reduced to a tenth
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Argentina cities: Mendoza; Timeline: none

Study: A Stratified Model to Quantify the Effects of Containment Policies on the Spread of COVID-19
Factors: lock-down: interactions of all individuals reduced to 10%

Measure of Evidence: Countries: Iran Timeline: first 90 days COVID-19 spread

The peak point is Feb. 17th, 2020 with 24,115 infected people and the end point is Jun. 17th, 2020. In t

Study: Effect of non-pharmaceutical interventions for containing the COVID-19 outbreak in China
Excerpt: 114,325 COVID-19 cases ( [IQR] 76,776 - 164,576); Without inner-city contact reduction, the number of COVID-19 cases would likely have shown a 1.0-fold increase (IQR: 0.6 - 1.4)

Study: Lessons learnt from 288 COVID-19 international cases: importations over time, effect of interventions, underdetection of imported cases
Excerpt: The model predicted a rapid exponential growth of importations from Hubei, with a growth rate = 0.26 [95% CI 0.21, 0.31], corresponding to a doubling time of 2.8 days; After the implementation of travel restrictions, a negative growth rate was estimated, signaling a decline in imported cases. The decline was sharp for Hubei (growth rate = -0.64 [-0.85, -0.48]) and more gradual for the rest of China (growth rate = -0.19 [-0.54, 0.00])
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; Timeline: Jan 3 to Feb 13, 2020

Study: Estimation of the epidemic properties of the 2019 novel coronavirus: A mathematical modeling study
Excerpt: Before the closure of Wuhan city the basic reproduction number of COVID-19 was 4.38 (95% CI: 3.63 – 5.13); dropping to 3.41 (95% CI: 3.16 – 3.65) after the closure of Wuhan city
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; cities: Wuhan; Timeline: 10th January to 23rd January (preclosure) and 23rd January to 8th February (after closure)

Study: Estimating the Efficacy of Traffic Blockage and Quarantine for the Epidemic Caused by 2019-nCoV (COVID-19)
Excerpt: current Hubei traffic blockage factor (HTbF)  0.66, current outside Hubei traffic blockage factor (oHTbF) 0.26; "HTbF increased by 0.01 peak infections decrease by 2.14%, oHTbF increased by 0.01 peak infections decrease by 4.01%, total traffic blockage - 21.06% - 22.39% decrease in peak value "

Study: Assessing the Impact of Reduced Travel on Exportation Dynamics of Novel Coronavirus Infection (COVID-19)
Factors: drastic reduction in travel volume within mainland China
Excerpt: the expected number of cases between Day 58 (28 January 2020) and Day 67 was 321 cases (95% confidence interval [CI]: 181, 544); Our estimate is consistent with an assessment by Chinazzi et al. [20], which indicated that the exported cases would be reduced by 80% by the end of February. In addition to appropriately quantifying the impact on prevention of exported cases, we have estimated the median time delay to a major epidemic assuming plausible values of R0 at 1.5, 2.2, and 3.7. With reduced probability of a major epidemic, the time delay to a major epidemic was estimated at a maximum of 2 days in Japan and a minimum of less than 1 day

Study: The Novel Coronavirus, 2019-nCoV, is Highly Contagious and More Infectious Than Initially Estimated
Factors: closure of Wuhan (and other cities in Hubei)
Excerpt: Ro between 4.7 to 6.6; Ro to between 2.3 to 3.0
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; cities: Wuhan; Timeline: Jan 15th- Jan 30th
